it's also gluten free so we're getting

of confectioner's sugar this recipe
actually uses two kinds of sugar
confectioner sugar here and then
granulated sugar in the egg whites which
is the base of this cookie I also want
to add a quarter teaspoon of fine salt
whisk all those dry ingredients together
it's a very simple recipe with a couple
of steps that are very important along
the way and then what you need to do is
pass it through a fine sieve this may
seem a little bit fussy but it's what

is really the only part that's gonna

that make for perfection I was so
surprised that so many people asked for
a French macaron I guess it's one of
those things that seem kind of elusive
and sort of mysterious so I'm really
happy to dispel the mystery I just went

start pressing through the last bits
because you want as much of the almond

possible and some of it is kind of
course all right now we can move on over
here I have four large egg whites I need
to whisk them until they're foamy
once it spelled me then you can add half
a cup of sugar with the Machine going
and whisk it until it's stiff and glossy
add a quarter teaspoon of almond extract
and then just beat everything until
stiff glossy peaks form to take about
five minutes once it's stiff and glossy
then you're just going to fold the egg
white mixture into your almond mixture
and then once it's all combined stir it
really vigorously what you're trying to
do is release the air bubbles you want
all the air bubbles out it shouldn't
take more than about 30 seconds it does
take a little bit of elbow grease so
don't give up and you want the mixture
to fall back on itself and be very
smooth kind of like a very thick honey
that smooths itself out almost
immediately when you stir it so if you
stop stirring it should fall into a
smooth mass basically immediately and
then you know you're done once it's all
mixed then what you want to do is
transfer it to a pastry bag I have a
pastry bag inside this quart container
makes it really easy to fill so just
pour the batter into your bag and then
fold the ends of the bag up out and then
you'll see that you have very clean top
which means that this stuff won't go
spurting everywhere and then cut off the
tip about a half an inch don't make too
big of a hole otherwise your batter will
come flying out twist it and then you're
ready to pipe and you can pipe onto
parchment lined baking sheets I like to
put a tiny dab of batter underneath each
corner to keep it in place while I'm
baking and then I just pipe the cookies
you can fit about five across lift your
bag up between each so that you don't
get your parchment messy and then to the
next one this will make about two trays
worth of cookies so that's quite a few
sandwich cookies but they are a special
cookie so you want to make sure there's
enough to share and then what you want
to do is you have to let these sit for
thirty minutes to one and a half hours
at room temperature uncovered what
that's going to do is allow the top to
get a little bit dry they're going to be
dry enough that you can touch the top
and that's what gives the cookies their
classic shape where they puff up the top
is flat and then there's a little bit of
separation between the bottom and the
top that's from the drying
350 degrees for about 16 minutes when
the cookies are done make sure you let
them cool completely on the parchment
paper on a wire rack then you can run an
offset spatula underneath them to loosen
them and they'll be like a pale tan
color nice and crisp on top and a little
bit chewy in the center you'll notice
that the tops are perfectly smooth and
flat and the sides have puffed up a
little bit and that's what letting them
sit until they're dry on top allows for
and then fill with whatever you like
today I'm using a strained raspberry jam
a little tiny bit goes a long way here I
would say a little more than a half a
